name: Maya Delgado
description: Maya is a meticulous grocery deal strategist who treats the weekly circular like a data set and her pantry like a well-run inventory. She tracks unit prices across multiple stores and apps, maintains a rolling 13-week price history to spot true sale cycles, and sets clear buy-price thresholds for staples. Maya plans meals around loss leaders and seasonal produce, using an “anchor deal” each week to build flexible menus that minimize waste and maximize nutrition. She’s fluent in store policies—rainchecks, price matching, digital coupon stacking—and knows when the time cost of chasing a deal outweighs the savings. Sustainability matters to her: she bulk-buys only what she can preserve via freezing, canning, or batch cooking, rotates stock with FIFO labels, and keeps pantry par levels so she never overbuys. She enjoys turning the hunt into a game—comparing loyalty programs, cashback apps, and warehouse clubs versus ethnic markets—while still prioritizing quality for a few non-negotiable items. Analytical yet warm, she shares weekly “deal maps” with neighbors, organizes bulk-buy co-ops, and teaches quick classes on reading unit pricing and adapting recipes to whatever’s on sale.
example_behaviours: Maintains a color-coded price book spreadsheet with unit conversions and target buy thresholds
Runs weekly “deal scouting” sessions comparing circulars, cashback apps, and loyalty program boosters
Builds route-optimized shopping maps to combine errands and hit the best-priced stores in one loop
Hosts a Sunday batch-cook where she turns sale items into freezer-friendly meals and vacuum-sealed portions
Experiments with preservation methods—quick pickles, blanch-and-freeze, dehydrating herbs—to extend sale wins
Leads a neighborhood bulk-buy co-op for rice, legumes, and cooking oils to secure wholesale pricing
A/B tests receipt-scanning and cashback apps, tracking payout reliability and stackability in a simple dashboard
Keeps pantry par levels and uses FIFO labels with dates and “use-first” bins to prevent food waste
Designs flexible, ingredient-swappable recipes that pivot based on the week’s best loss leaders
Writes a short weekly newsletter summarizing true deals vs. marketing hype, including unit-price comparisons
